 EgpLon Mt,amy.-Two nAanuscrpts on papyrus were lately unfolded from the head and breast Ol Mummy opened at Paris. Such was their state of preservation that scientific person present, immed aIey pronounced the body have been that of Tete Muchis, the daughter of the keeper of the Temple of Isis, at Thebes.

 At late session of the U S Circuit Court at Rich mond Vir Chief Justice Marshall presiding John B. Amedie was tried for the crime of destroying vessel at sea, of which he was commander for the purnose of dCfrautng the underwriters. He found guilty and sentenced to be hung the 18th of th;s month.

 The finances of the Brazilian government were in a deplorable condition, the revenue from the customs having greatly diminished, and the bank paper (of which may be said there upwards of IS millions in circuationj having Appreciated 5 per cent since the commencement of the war.  O'oination-On Wednesday the 9th inst at Christ Church in Hartford, by the Rt. Rev. Bishop Brow nell the Rev. John G. Stone ofthis town, was admit ted to the Holy Order of Priests.

 MT. Norman Pinney, Tutor of Mathematics in Washington College, was the same day admitted to the Holy Ordinance of Deacons. MT. Pinncy was presented by the Rev. Hector Humphreys.-Sermon by the Rev. Rodney Rossiter.

 Ordination-In Boston, on the 27th ult. the Rev. HERvEY HAYES received ordination as an Evangelist Introductory prayer by the Rev. B. B. Wisner mon from Isa 50: 8, 9, by the Rev. L. Beecher, D. o.; consecratng prayer by the Rev. W. Fay; charge by the Rev. w. Jenks D. D.; fellowship by the Rev. F. Beecher concluding prayer by the Rev: s. Green. MT. Hayes is appointed Chaplain of the z. &. ship Jaua, which is destined for the Mediterranean. The introduction of an evangelical minister on board of war, into congregation of five hundred souls is an event of no ordinary importance; especially we learn the Secretary of the Navy will in future require that all Chaplans in the service be regularly ordained

The same paper of later dAie contains the follow ing paragraph :-

 On the 4Ih of March the Ottoman troops attacked the three towers which General Callerghi had made himself master of a few days before in the Prseus Both parties fought desperately from the morning til the evening The Turks had 700 killed and 3OG wounded The Greeks had only ten killed and % wounded. On the 2d of March a proclamation of the Government was published, announcing the blockade of the ports of TriGer and MaO as well as the whole Island of Euboea, with view to off the supplies ade was entrusted to the Helas frigate, commanded by Maulls; the Perseverance steam boat; and the lpsariot brig the Nelson, commanded by Captain Di- mltrl FaPa-Ncoil. Some troops on board were to land at Oropo, where are the magazines of Redschd Pacha The expedition was to be directed by the Bavarian Colonel Chares d d'Heideck tHeidegger).

 karaiskaki, after having provided for the defence of Western Greece, had marched towards Attica.

 Coetti, of Tallante, had cut of all communications between Redschid Pacha and Volo, where the Seras- kler has his magazines of wheat.

 Oh the 7th of March, the plenpotcntaries at Egina declared themselves ready begin their sessions der Notara as president.

 The opposition Journals lately inserted an article from the Oriental Spectator in which Austria was re- presented as opposed to the negotiations favor of the Greeks. We find the following passage in the Aus trtnn O6SerUeT, under the head of Constantinope :

 The new ordinances, as well as the preparations for the campaign this year against the insurgents have, for some time past excited, in high degree, the at tenton of the public, who extremely desirous to see an end put to the confusion and disorder which some years the reVOted countries wish which is shared by all the friends of human ity and is continually advocated the Porte by the Ambassadors of the European Powers whose constant efforts tend to the establishment and preservation of tranquility in Europe.''

 The Egyptian naval troops wear white uniform with red sashes and a red cap with anchor. All th1s seems the more singular the Turkish seamen, and especially those of the Barbary States are coth- ed m miserable rags of all colours -''

 The following appears in the London New Times, Of April Both.

 CoNsrANTINoPLE, March 27th.

 In the circles of European merchants at Pera, an extract circulated of the protocol of the conferences of the 4th of April signed at St. Petersburgby Counts Nesserode and Liven on the one part, and the Duke warrant the authenticity of it, send you general view of the contents. The High Contracting Powers having alleged the principles of humanity and religion, which make them desirous of seeing end put to the contest in Greece and the Archipelago, declare that they have agreed that the modification already offered by England shall rest on the following basis :" That the Greeks shall remain dependent on the Ottoman Porte and that annual tribute, tobe paid by them, shall be definitely ixed-that, the mixture of the Turks and Greeks in these countries is attended with great nconvenences estimate shall be made Of the Turkish property in the Morea and the islands, and the value shall be paid by the Greeks to the propre- tors-that the Magistrates in Greece shall be named by the Greeks but with the cooperation of the Porte but the Greeks shall have the free exercise of their religion and of commerce, and also separate and in dependent Administration-that, if the mediation of England should already be accepted by the Porte, Russia shall at all events it's influence promote the of this intervention the time and the man. of this participation, shall, however be previously determined by Convention between England and the Porte-that ln case the mediation should be declined by the Porte, without regard the state of the other relations between his Imperial Majesty and the Turk ish Government Russia and Great Britain will always consider the abe!e points the basis of the reconc- iation, and embrace every favorable opportunity to promote them, both singy and conjontly-that an a. greement shall be made respecting the details of the determination of the boundaries of the territory the Continent and in the siandsthat the two Powers will not seek to acquire any increase of territory, eX- elusive influence, commercial advantages for their subjects which might not be obtained by every na- tionthat the two Powers desire the concurrence of the Allied Powers in the preliminary arrangement, which shall be communicated to the Cabinets of Vi- enna, Berlin and Pars with the proposal 10 guaran- tee m concert with Rnssia the final arrangement for the a of Turkey and Greece as his n Ma himself this rantee."-AHgeimGne ZeitWng.

 CoSsTANTINoPLE March 26.

 The anxiety excited by "e negotiations of the Rus sian and English Mnis has risen to the highest pitch The Porte, and particu arly the Sultan, will hear either of the qualification of Greece of the intervention ef the European powers this Subject and the irritation of the Mussumans has been increa sed by the news of the advantages obtained by the Greeks so that it would be easy for the Government send fresh troops to the theatre of war, continue the contest. The Refs Efendi, who, however, jected every proposal, is accused of acting with too much lukewarmncss in not rejecting them once for all. However this may be, he has been dismissed, and the Franks say, may think himself happy have tired so honourably. His successor is considered true Mussulman.

 CoNsTANrINoPLE, March 25.

 It is said that the Servans have opposed, in arms, the introduction, by tie Pacha of Belgrade of more than 500 of the troops into the fortresses depen dent on his government Three new deputies have been chosen to go to Constantinople, attended by secretary.A

 The Muhurdar of Kosrew Pacha, the late High Admiral has received the two tails, as a reward for his zeal and aptness in learning the new military ex- ercise.

 The first regiment of new troopo, 3OOO strong be- sides l80 horsemen, has gone to join the Army in Ru- melia. It has marched to Daoud Pacha, and has been received by the Sultan. Another regiment is come from Scutari take its place in the barracksof Eski Serai; 5000 men had previously marched to La rissa; 1000 men of the 2d regiment set out on the 22d from Eski Serai, for Daoud Pacha, with twelve cannon in the same order, and with the same ceremo nies as the preceding.

 The Greek Patriarch has exiled the Metropotans of EpheMs, Heraclea, Demotica and Janina.

 Eight hundred cavalry horses have arrived from the principalites the Danube. Nearly an equal number has been sent to the Government by different Pachas.

 It is said that funds have been Reschid Pa cha to enlist l0,000 Albanians.

 Ten corvettes and two brgs are at anchor of the Sultans summer palace, and will sail with the first good wind, under the command of Natl Bey, who IS appointed Serasker of the fleet. It is thought he will go directly Syra land in that island which isthe enrepot for the commerce, and supply of the Greeks m the Archlpelago "a

THE CABINET.

measures which chey now support and approve. Can did men arc willing to look upon political alterations as they do upon moral. The man who has once done wrong, but who now, and for many years past, has walked uprightly, is not by acquainted with the failties of human nature, censured and dcondemned- He who is at all acquainted with the political history of our country, and with the various questions which have agitated and distracted national councils, be convinced that if political repentance be cessay for party, class of men, is also equal ly necessary for the otherthat if individuals of one political name are to be ccnsured for an undue regard party lines-for strenuous adhesion party prin- cples to the detriment of the country individuals of the other political not free from the same charge-they also actuated by equally strong prejudice for the name by which they called.- Although these party not entirely forgotten, discarded yet when they are applied, it is in the most unmeaning manner, and without any regard to the character which should be attached them. Men who were foremost in the democratic ranks, when measures contended for, now accused offed- eraism, while others, whose every act strongly marked with federalism, have recently been embraced democrats, and that without any other evidence political recantaon, than violent zeal for Whatever may be said against political amalgamaon, we have it in the strongest of the term. The old lines of distinction completely broken down, that appears almost impossible to know by what po- litical name a man should be called His acts will not speak for him. for support ofthe measures which in place entitle him the name of republican, draw upon him from another quarter the charge of federalism. Men are called republican tbis year, and without the shadow of change in their principles. are next year called federal and so conrariwise.- This is confirmation strong that party names known 30 years ago. have lost all their meaning; that they arc worthless appendage to the political nomencla- lure, and that they will shortly be swallowed up by the new which will be assumed by the Adams and Jackson partizans.

 Senator for Mdssachusetts.--We learn from the Boston papers, that the 7th inst the House ofRep- resentatives of Mass. chose by large majority, Hon. DANIEL WEBSTER, present representative in Congress from Suffolk district Senator in Congress for six years from the fourth of March last. Whole number of votes given, 323,-necessary for choice, 165-Mr. Webster had 2O2, and was declared elected. On Friday the election took place in the upper House. and the choice of the lower House was concurred in by 26 votes out of 39 Relative this election, we apply the sentiment which a certain Jackson print uScu "hCA POIuIS Nit cicCuoH Ol M LdNeJ OI Delaware to the same important station |" Massachu- sets has covered herself with glory" This sentiment we most heartily reiterate, cut where it will. We are glad to the good of the republicans of Mass placing truly great men in exalted stations, and wish their principles might be more generally adopted country then might derive important advantage from the talents of her richly gifted but things too often are, of acknowledged eminence are of ten driven into the back ground, simply because they do not belong to "my party" did support the measures which 'I Iconsderedrepublican." These party shackles Massachusetts has thrown oE-but we will say just at present, for fear of rendering furious certain brother editor fifty miles off, who in all conscience will feel enough when he re- ports the "glorious news"

 Hon. Wm c. Jarvis, of Pittsfield has been elected Treasurer of the State of Mass and on not being able Co procure the requisite security of 100000, for the faithful performance of the duties of the station has bcen obliged to decline. So says one account; we can hardly credit the story, however, from the high esteem in which Mr. Jarvis has been held in Berk- shire county, where there is wealth enough surely.- But such things have been, and snotmpossble that they may occur again.

 MASSACHUSETTS, LEGISLATURE.

 The session commenced "Wednesday, May 30. Gov. Lincoln and It. Gov. Winthrop were reelected by large majorities. Hon. John Mills is again Presi- dent of the Senate. Hon. W. c. Jarvis was again chosen Speaker of the House, and ociaed for seve- ral days, when he chosen Treasurer of the Com- monweah, the former incumbent being no longer el- igble by the constitution. E. D. Bangs re-clec- ted Secretary. The vacancies in the Senate have been filled in the Senate follows, by the houses in convention: Suffolk, T. Welsh Jr., c. Loring, F. C. Gray, N. P. Russell Bristol, L. Williams Jr. and H. Lathrop. Worcester, J. Bowman. Franklin, T. Longley-Rev. Dr. Jenks is chaplain of the Senate Rev. Geo. Ripley, chaplain of the house. Many pri- vate petitions have been presented. As the session will be short it is probable that subjects of general and public nature will be understood.

If the package did not arrive in Hartford, the fault is in the Post Masters, not in The editor of the Times has the number an qUes- ton, and as it contains subjects entitled to grave and cOnsideraie attentOn," we may expect in due time some notice of it from the pen of Mr. Wells: in the mean time we shall content ourselves in reminding the editor that those who throw brck-bats and stOnes" ought not to complain at having their knuckles raped occasionally. When the editor of the Times shall write something in relation to o political course which is tangible, may think it profitable to reply to him ;- when he shall of the reasons which induced him |" to discard time pas" we shall be pre- pared to hold controversy with him. This viliyng,

 low bihhgsgate slang, is entirely unworthy decent paper, and we shall not foul columns with any pication to his abuse.

Longley-Rev Dr. Jenks is chaplain of the Senate Rev. Geo. Ripley, chaplain of the house. Many pri- vate petitions have been presented. As the session will be short, is probable that subjects of general and public nature will be understood.

 Stage AccideRt.-We learn that one of the Boston and Albany stages, via Greenfield and Wiiliamstown, while descending hill in Shelburne, three or four days snce was by freak of the horses overset. Several members of the Mass. Legislature in the coach at the ome, one of whom (Sfr. Putnam of Ad- amS,l had his arm broken, ond left with one of his companions at public house. Two or three oth- CTS were considerably injured, but no lives lost

 The WiHiamstown (Mass) paper Aates that flock o wolves have recently made their appearance in the northwest part of Berkshire county and that the des sructon of sheep by these prowlng monsters hasbeen very great In the town of ofLanesborough above about three hundred sheep have been killed and in Of the neghborng places the losses to the sheep have been proportionably great. That section of country, on account of the great number of sheep owned there, must afford fine range for wolves, while its almost mpenetrabe mountain forests w SC. cure them pretty safe retreat from the 1nraged far mers. An attempt was made last week to dsodge the depredators in concerted attack from four ouar. cers by the inhabitants of four towns. By some mis- understanding the project did not succeed and anoth- similar expedition is contemplated. 1.-the sports men of that vicinity have Putnam lead them to the attack shall hear of lots of wolves ears ta- ken of in Berkshire county.

 The editor of the Times positively asserts in his last that he did receive paper of the l7th ultmo, and also that several others whomt senn Hart ford, did not receive it. We willing to believe the assertion inasmuch others to whom the paper was directed say did not their hands. We mail ed the papers usual directed to all our exchanges

 Also on the 9th the wife of Mir. Harmon Osborn a. ged 36.

the work will contain notices of their scenery and gro auctions and of the and habits of the eoriC with statements illustrating their former condition an present improvements, Nc. Ac. It will also be ac- companied by Photographic Sketches of some Oi the most interesting scenes in that group of islands. ~. !. Spec.

 EgpLon Mt,amy.-Two nAanuscrpts on papyrus were lately unfolded from the head and breast Ol Mummy opened at Paris. Such was their state of preservation that scientific person present, immed aIey pronounced the body have been that of Tete Muchis, the daughter of the keeper of the Temple of Isis, at Thebes.

 At late session of the U S Circuit Court at Rich mond Vir Chief Justice Marshall presiding John B. Amedie was tried for the crime of destroying vessel at sea, of which he was commander for the purnose of dCfrautng the underwriters. He found guilty and sentenced to be hung the 18th of th;s month.

 The finances of the Brazilian government were in a deplorable condition, the revenue from the customs having greatly diminished, and the bank paper (of which may be said there upwards of IS millions in circuationj having Appreciated 5 per cent since the commencement of the war. A few days before the Florida sailed, the exigencies of the trea- sury, large lot of the crown jewels offered at public sale at the bank and withdrawn mo purchasers coming forward

 The last benefactions of the late Mr. Philips whose death was announced in last paper topublic char ities were-to Philips Academy $15, ,000-Theolog- cal Institution $10,000-Socety for propogating the Gospel $5,0O0-Mass. Bible Society $5, ,0OO-Fo Foreign Mission Society $5,OOO-Medica Dspensary 5000 Mass Gen Hospital for the relief of sick poor of Bos ton $5,000--Am. Ed Society $5,00O-Female Asy- lum &, ,0O0-Asylum for Indigcnt Boys S2,0o0-MasS. Cong. Charitable Socciety $5,O0o-Total, $62,C00

 O'oination-On Wednesday the 9th inst at Christ Church in Hartford, by the Rt. Rev. Bishop Brow nell the Rev. John G. Stone ofthis town, was admit ted to the Holy Order of Priests.

 MT. Norman Pinney, Tutor of Mathematics in Washington College, was the same day admitted to the Holy Ordinance of Deacons. MT. Pinncy was presented by the Rev. Hector Humphreys.-Sermon by the Rev. Rodney Rossiter.

 Ordination-In Boston, on the 27th ult. the Rev. HERvEY HAYES received ordination as an Evangelist Introductory prayer by the Rev. B. B. Wisner mon from Isa 50: 8, 9, by the Rev. L. Beecher, D. o.; consecratng prayer by the Rev. W. Fay; charge by the Rev. w. Jenks D. D.; fellowship by the Rev. F. Beecher concluding prayer by the Rev: s. Green. MT. Hayes is appointed Chaplain of the z. &. ship Jaua, which is destined for the Mediterranean. The introduction of an evangelical minister on board of war, into congregation of five hundred souls is an event of no ordinary importance; especially we learn the Secretary of the Navy will in future require that all Chaplans in the service be regularly ordained

We had not room 10 copy many of these But their general aspect is fvourable Indeed counts from Greece are favourable The Egna Ga zee, of Feb 18th, says the Turkish garrsons of Sa

 Iona have abandoned that fortress, which has fallen Greece is no-v free" Omar Pacha was routed at

 Iune If.

The same paper of later dAie contains the follow ing paragraph :-

 On the 4Ih of March the Ottoman troops attacked the three towers which General Callerghi had made himself master of a few days before in the Prseus Both parties fought desperately from the morning til the evening The Turks had 700 killed and 3OG wounded The Greeks had only ten killed and % wounded. On the 2d of March a proclamation of the Government was published, announcing the blockade of the ports of TriGer and MaO as well as the whole Island of Euboea, with view to off the supplies ade was entrusted to the Helas frigate, commanded by Maulls; the Perseverance steam boat; and the lpsariot brig the Nelson, commanded by Captain Di- mltrl FaPa-Ncoil. Some troops on board were to land at Oropo, where are the magazines of Redschd Pacha The expedition was to be directed by the Bavarian Colonel Chares d d'Heideck tHeidegger).

 karaiskaki, after having provided for the defence of Western Greece, had marched towards Attica.

 Coetti, of Tallante, had cut of all communications between Redschid Pacha and Volo, where the Seras- kler has his magazines of wheat.

 Oh the 7th of March, the plenpotcntaries at Egina declared themselves ready begin their sessions der Notara as president.

 The opposition Journals lately inserted an article from the Oriental Spectator in which Austria was re- presented as opposed to the negotiations favor of the Greeks. We find the following passage in the Aus trtnn O6SerUeT, under the head of Constantinope :

 The new ordinances, as well as the preparations for the campaign this year against the insurgents have, for some time past excited, in high degree, the at tenton of the public, who extremely desirous to see an end put to the confusion and disorder which some years the reVOted countries wish which is shared by all the friends of human ity and is continually advocated the Porte by the Ambassadors of the European Powers whose constant efforts tend to the establishment and preservation of tranquility in Europe.''

 The Egyptian naval troops wear white uniform with red sashes and a red cap with anchor. All th1s seems the more singular the Turkish seamen, and especially those of the Barbary States are coth- ed m miserable rags of all colours -''

 The following appears in the London New Times, Of April Both.

 CoNsrANTINoPLE, March 27th.

 In the circles of European merchants at Pera, an extract circulated of the protocol of the conferences of the 4th of April signed at St. Petersburgby Counts Nesserode and Liven on the one part, and the Duke warrant the authenticity of it, send you general view of the contents. The High Contracting Powers having alleged the principles of humanity and religion, which make them desirous of seeing end put to the contest in Greece and the Archipelago, declare that they have agreed that the modification already offered by England shall rest on the following basis :" That the Greeks shall remain dependent on the Ottoman Porte and that annual tribute, tobe paid by them, shall be definitely ixed-that, the mixture of the Turks and Greeks in these countries is attended with great nconvenences estimate shall be made Of the Turkish property in the Morea and the islands, and the value shall be paid by the Greeks to the propre- tors-that the Magistrates in Greece shall be named by the Greeks but with the cooperation of the Porte but the Greeks shall have the free exercise of their religion and of commerce, and also separate and in dependent Administration-that, if the mediation of England should already be accepted by the Porte, Russia shall at all events it's influence promote the of this intervention the time and the man. of this participation, shall, however be previously determined by Convention between England and the Porte-that ln case the mediation should be declined by the Porte, without regard the state of the other relations between his Imperial Majesty and the Turk ish Government Russia and Great Britain will always consider the abe!e points the basis of the reconc- iation, and embrace every favorable opportunity to promote them, both singy and conjontly-that an a. greement shall be made respecting the details of the determination of the boundaries of the territory the Continent and in the siandsthat the two Powers will not seek to acquire any increase of territory, eX- elusive influence, commercial advantages for their subjects which might not be obtained by every na- tionthat the two Powers desire the concurrence of the Allied Powers in the preliminary arrangement, which shall be communicated to the Cabinets of Vi- enna, Berlin and Pars with the proposal 10 guaran- tee m concert with Rnssia the final arrangement for the a of Turkey and Greece as his n Ma himself this rantee."-AHgeimGne ZeitWng.

 CoSsTANTINoPLE March 26.

 The anxiety excited by "e negotiations of the Rus sian and English Mnis has risen to the highest pitch The Porte, and particu arly the Sultan, will hear either of the qualification of Greece of the intervention ef the European powers this Subject and the irritation of the Mussumans has been increa sed by the news of the advantages obtained by the Greeks so that it would be easy for the Government send fresh troops to the theatre of war, continue the contest. The Refs Efendi, who, however, jected every proposal, is accused of acting with too much lukewarmncss in not rejecting them once for all. However this may be, he has been dismissed, and the Franks say, may think himself happy have tired so honourably. His successor is considered true Mussulman.

 CoNsTANrINoPLE, March 25.

 It is said that the Servans have opposed, in arms, the introduction, by tie Pacha of Belgrade of more than 500 of the troops into the fortresses depen dent on his government Three new deputies have been chosen to go to Constantinople, attended by secretary.A

 The Muhurdar of Kosrew Pacha, the late High Admiral has received the two tails, as a reward for his zeal and aptness in learning the new military ex- ercise.

 The first regiment of new troopo, 3OOO strong be- sides l80 horsemen, has gone to join the Army in Ru- melia. It has marched to Daoud Pacha, and has been received by the Sultan. Another regiment is come from Scutari take its place in the barracksof Eski Serai; 5000 men had previously marched to La rissa; 1000 men of the 2d regiment set out on the 22d from Eski Serai, for Daoud Pacha, with twelve cannon in the same order, and with the same ceremo nies as the preceding.

 The Greek Patriarch has exiled the Metropotans of EpheMs, Heraclea, Demotica and Janina.

 Eight hundred cavalry horses have arrived from the principalites the Danube. Nearly an equal number has been sent to the Government by different Pachas.

 It is said that funds have been Reschid Pa cha to enlist l0,000 Albanians.

 Ten corvettes and two brgs are at anchor of the Sultans summer palace, and will sail with the first good wind, under the command of Natl Bey, who IS appointed Serasker of the fleet. It is thought he will go directly Syra land in that island which isthe enrepot for the commerce, and supply of the Greeks m the Archlpelago "a

measures which chey now support and approve. Can did men arc willing to look upon political alterations as they do upon moral. The man who has once done wrong, but who now, and for many years past, has walked uprightly, is not by acquainted with the failties of human nature, censured and dcondemned- He who is at all acquainted with the political history of our country, and with the various questions which have agitated and distracted national councils, be convinced that if political repentance be cessay for party, class of men, is also equal ly necessary for the otherthat if individuals of one political name are to be ccnsured for an undue regard party lines-for strenuous adhesion party prin- cples to the detriment of the country individuals of the other political not free from the same charge-they also actuated by equally strong prejudice for the name by which they called.- Although these party not entirely forgotten, discarded yet when they are applied, it is in the most unmeaning manner, and without any regard to the character which should be attached them. Men who were foremost in the democratic ranks, when measures contended for, now accused offed- eraism, while others, whose every act strongly marked with federalism, have recently been embraced democrats, and that without any other evidence political recantaon, than violent zeal for Whatever may be said against political amalgamaon, we have it in the strongest of the term. The old lines of distinction completely broken down, that appears almost impossible to know by what po- litical name a man should be called His acts will not speak for him. for support ofthe measures which in place entitle him the name of republican, draw upon him from another quarter the charge of federalism. Men are called republican tbis year, and without the shadow of change in their principles. are next year called federal and so conrariwise.- This is confirmation strong that party names known 30 years ago. have lost all their meaning; that they arc worthless appendage to the political nomencla- lure, and that they will shortly be swallowed up by the new which will be assumed by the Adams and Jackson partizans.

 Senator for Mdssachusetts.--We learn from the Boston papers, that the 7th inst the House ofRep- resentatives of Mass. chose by large majority, Hon. DANIEL WEBSTER, present representative in Congress from Suffolk district Senator in Congress for six years from the fourth of March last. Whole number of votes given, 323,-necessary for choice, 165-Mr. Webster had 2O2, and was declared elected. On Friday the election took place in the upper House. and the choice of the lower House was concurred in by 26 votes out of 39 Relative this election, we apply the sentiment which a certain Jackson print uScu "hCA POIuIS Nit cicCuoH Ol M LdNeJ OI Delaware to the same important station |" Massachu- sets has covered herself with glory" This sentiment we most heartily reiterate, cut where it will. We are glad to the good of the republicans of Mass placing truly great men in exalted stations, and wish their principles might be more generally adopted country then might derive important advantage from the talents of her richly gifted but things too often are, of acknowledged eminence are of ten driven into the back ground, simply because they do not belong to "my party" did support the measures which 'I Iconsderedrepublican." These party shackles Massachusetts has thrown oE-but we will say just at present, for fear of rendering furious certain brother editor fifty miles off, who in all conscience will feel enough when he re- ports the "glorious news"

 Hon. Wm c. Jarvis, of Pittsfield has been elected Treasurer of the State of Mass and on not being able Co procure the requisite security of 100000, for the faithful performance of the duties of the station has bcen obliged to decline. So says one account; we can hardly credit the story, however, from the high esteem in which Mr. Jarvis has been held in Berk- shire county, where there is wealth enough surely.- But such things have been, and snotmpossble that they may occur again.

 MASSACHUSETTS, LEGISLATURE.

 The session commenced "Wednesday, May 30. Gov. Lincoln and It. Gov. Winthrop were reelected by large majorities. Hon. John Mills is again Presi- dent of the Senate. Hon. W. c. Jarvis was again chosen Speaker of the House, and ociaed for seve- ral days, when he chosen Treasurer of the Com- monweah, the former incumbent being no longer el- igble by the constitution. E. D. Bangs re-clec- ted Secretary. The vacancies in the Senate have been filled in the Senate follows, by the houses in convention: Suffolk, T. Welsh Jr., c. Loring, F. C. Gray, N. P. Russell Bristol, L. Williams Jr. and H. Lathrop. Worcester, J. Bowman. Franklin, T. Longley-Rev. Dr. Jenks is chaplain of the Senate Rev. Geo. Ripley, chaplain of the house. Many pri- vate petitions have been presented. As the session will be short it is probable that subjects of general and public nature will be understood.

 Stage AccideRt.-We learn that one of the Boston and Albany stages via Greenfield and Wiiliamstown, while descending hill in Shelburne. three or four days since, by freak of the horses overset. CALEB REYNOLDS ESTATE. The Hon. Court of Probate for the district Of Sharon hath assigned Tuesday, the 26th day of June inst. at 9 o'clock in the forenoon, at the Probate Office in Salisbury, for the settlement of the accounts of the Administra- tor upon the estate of Caleb Reyaolds, late of Sharon, in said district. deceased.

 By order of Court,

 ORRIN CLARK, Administrator. Sharon, June 5. 1827. 59

m Hartford, and also to some ten or fifteen members of the Legislature. If the package did not arrive in Hartford, the fault is in the Post Masters, not in The editor of the Times has the number an qUes- ton, and as it contains subjects entitled to grave and cOnsideraie attentOn," we may expect in due time some notice of it from the pen of Mr. Wells: in the mean time we shall content ourselves in reminding the editor that those who throw brck-bats and stOnes" ought not to complain at having their knuckles raped occasionally. When the editor of the Times shall write something in relation to o political course which is tangible, may think it profitable to reply to him ;- when he shall of the reasons which induced him |" to discard time pas" we shall be pre- pared to hold controversy with him. This viliyng,

 low bihhgsgate slang, is entirely unworthy decent paper, and we shall not foul columns with any pication to his abuse.

Longley-Rev Dr. Jenks is chaplain of the Senate Rev. Geo. Ripley, chaplain of the house. Many pri- vate petitions have been presented. As the session will be short, is probable that subjects of general and public nature will be understood.

That section of country, on account of the great number of sheep owned there, must afford fine range for wolves, while its almost mpenetrabe mountain forests w SC. cure them pretty safe retreat from the 1nraged far mers.
